awd_titl_txt: Unfolding the Dynamic and Colorful Lives of Compact Object Mergers
awd_abstract_narration:
The mergers of two astronomical compact objects (neutron stars and/or black holes) in a binary system serve as sources of gravitational wave emission, potential sites of heavy element nucleosynthesis, and laboratories for high-energy astrophysical processes not seen elsewhere in the universe. With the onset of advanced gravitational wave detectors, only recently have astronomers begun to place direct constraints on these processes. Short gamma-ray bursts (SGRBs), which are detected at cosmological distances, also offer a unique and independent window into the dynamic and colorful lives of compact object mergers. A research group at Northwestern University, under the direction of the principal investigator (PI), will capitalize on complementary streams of data from gravitational wave observatories, ground-based telescopes and space-based gamma-ray and X-ray missions to: (i) develop informed follow-up strategies for electromagnetic (EM) observations following gravitational wave events, (ii) confront theoretical models of heavy element production in mergers with optical and near-infrared observations, (iii) place constraints on the fraction of mergers that produce SGRBs with radio through X-ray observations, and (iv) decipher the histories of the pre-merger binary systems with a complete census of their host galaxies.  To make this research publicly accessible in a novel way, the PI will partner with Evanston (Illinois) Township High School (ETHS) which has an on-campus planetarium. The PI will use the planetarium as a venue for engaging students with research material and exposing students to Astronomy researchers from diverse backgrounds.

The research group will utilize the inferred properties of previous SGRBs to build light curve prediction tools that will optimize an observatory's chance of an EM counterpart detection following a gravitational wave event. These adaptable tools will serve as an important community resource, not only for determining current observing strategies but also for planning future EM surveys. The research group will also place direct, observational constraints on the role of mergers in populating the Universe with heavy elements, by determining independently-measured ejecta masses and event rates.  The researchers will build a complete census of SGRB host galaxies and the spatial offsets of bursts from the galaxy centers.  From these observations, the researchers will determine the distributions of merger kick velocities and delay times. These distributions are vital inputs for binary evolution models, yet they are highly uncertain. The project is well-designed to exploit both methods of merger discovery: gravitational wave emission from Advanced LIGO/Virgo and gamma-ray burst detection from space-based missions.  For all objectives in this proposal, the research group will make crucial connections between the local population of compact object mergers discovered by Advanced LIGO/Virgo and their cosmological analogues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall focus of this project was to characterize the population of one of the most luminous transients in the universe: short-duration gamma-ray bursts (SGRBs). SGRBs originate from the mergers of two neutron stars (NS-NS) and/or the mergers of neutron stars with black holes (NS-BH). Our team used observations across the electromagnetic spectrum to provide a holistic view of SGRBs. In addition, NS-NS/NS-BH mergers are primary sources for detectable gravitational wave emission, and thus directly connects to the exciting era of multi-messenger astronomy. Multi-messenger astronomy is an NSF Big Idea and is an international scientific priority.

The major goals of this project were to (1) Develop and implement informed observational search strategies following GW events; (2) Explore the role of neutron star binary and neutron star-black hole mergers in the nucleosynthesis of heavy elements; (3) Place constraints on the fraction of such mergers that produce short gamma-ray bursts; and (4) Decipher the histories of the binary systems prior to merger.

Among numerous outcomes, some key results include: (1) The discovery of an extremely luminous kilonova associated with the short GRB 200522A. The luminosity of this event is thought to be powered by a magnetar, and was enabled by Hubble Space Telescope observations; (2) The largest catalog to ever exist of SGRB host galaxies, which demonstrate what types of galaxies they occur in to provide context for what environmental conditions can breed these rare explosions; (3) a demonstration that the rates of SGRBs are comparable to those of NS-NS binaries, but are far more numerous than that of NS-BH binaries indicating that most SGRBs originate from NS-NS mergers; (4) the discovery of the first kilonova from a long-duration GRB, explosions which typically spawn from massive star collapses. This unexpected discovery is a first-of-its-kind in the field; (5) a theoretical study showing that the rates of NS-NS mergers in dense star clusters are far fewer than had been anticipated; (6) a key constraint on the maximum mass of a cold non-rotating NS of M < 2.4 Msol, complementary to pulsar studies; (7) Discovery of the most distant SGRB with optical light to date, SGRB 181123B at z=1.754. We used Gemini-North, Keck and the MMT to uncover its host galaxy. We also made predictions for the number of high-redshift short GRBs which are expected given different delay time distribution models.

This project resulted in 16 peer-reviewed publications, the large majority of which were led by students or postdocs. The grant also enabled the training of 6 graduate students and postdoctoral associates, and 8 undergraduates from across the country. The results were disseminated in public talks, and engagement with the Chicago community. Members of our team also participated as mentors in CIERA's REU program funded by the NSF. We also provided scholarships for CIERA's summer high school program, REACH and provided mentorship in terms of both research and basic astronomy training.
